review.title: A Rule-Based Short Query Intent Identification System
review.abstract: Using SMS (Short Message System), cell phones can be used to query for information about various topics. In an SMS based search system, one of the key problems is to identify a domain (broad topic) associated with the user query; so that a more comprehensive search can be carried out by the domain specific search engine. In this paper we use a rule based approach, to identify the domain, called Short Query Intent Identification System (SQIIS). We construct two different rule-bases using different strategies to suit query intent identification. We evaluate the two rule-bases experimentally.

sections.heading: A. Tagging
sections.text: SQIIS breaks down the input query into word tokens by n-gram analysis in a first step. Thus, a token can contain one or more words in the input query. The tagging process takes place on the token. Formally, the tagging process is carried out as shown below.

If the token in a particular lookup table matches, then the tag associated with the lookup table is appended to this token. sections.heading: C. Rule Based Domain Identification Phase
sections.text: Each tuple (row) represents a rule. Each tuple has a combination of tags and a set of domains and confidentialities. If a certain combination of tags corresponds to a tag combination associated with a rule, then the rule is "fired" and the domains and their corresponding confidentialities are returned. If a certain combination of tags occurs, then it can be said that the query belongs to a certain domain with a certain degree of security. If the trust for a certain domain is high for a certain combination of tags, then there is a higher probability that this query belongs to that domain or can be accurately associated with it. We know that the output from the tagging phase is Q = {w1 [t1], w2 [t2]......, wj [tj]} format. sections.heading: E. System Description
sections.text: The built-in functionality system consists of three domains, Yellow Pages, Movie and Road Map Domains. There are a total of seven tags: T = {Address, Category, Proper Name, Movie Title, Movie Actor (Proper Name), Movie Actor (Category), Direction Word}. The address tag is assigned to a general address element, such as street, street or street name, or city area. The category tag is assigned to keywords, such as restaurant, theater, club, bank, hospital. A proper name is the name of a person, company, etc. The tags described above can be generally associated with yellow pages. The directional word tag is assigned to words such as from, to, way to, etc. The proper name of the movie title is partially or entirely associated with movie names, category of movie actors refers to keywords such as actor, music director, etc. The proper name of the movie actor refers to names of movie personalities.

sections.heading: A. System Generated or Semi Supervised Rule Base
sections.text: The strategy for developing a rule base is a semi-automatic process. The developed method is based on the premise that when a certain tag occurs, there is a higher probability that the tag combination belongs to a certain domain. Here, a weight is set for each tag and domain pair, namely (ti, dj) → wij. If the tag ti occurs in the query, then the weight wij is assigned to the domain j. Formally, for each day ti in sentence T and domain dj in sentence D a weight wij is assigned, namely (ti, dj) → wij. The trust of a domain dk, the trust (dk) for a tag combination (t1, t2,....., tn) is given as trust (dk) = n1i ikw. If there is a certain number of domains in the group D of domains within which the system operates, trust in a domain is normalized.
